Your fiddle produces the following error:

> Uncaught RangeError: byte length of Float32Array should be a multiple of 4

I think this message is more or less self explaining. Besides, I've seen two errors in your first fiddle:

http://jsfiddle.net/zape7z10/7/

1. `InterleavedBuffer` has only two parameters. When creating `classifBf`, you assign a third one.
2. The third paramter of `InterleavedBufferAttribute` is the `offset` in the buffer where you attribute data starts. Both are `0` in your example which is wrong.

Both errors are fixed in this updated [fiddle](http://jsfiddle.net/zape7z10/8/). Now you also have a correct visual result.

> What would be the best way to achieve that?

Do it like in your first example. Or try to work with a padding to fill up the missing bytes. For more help, please use the [forum](https://discourse.threejs.org/) or stackoverflow.

@Mugen87 Apparently I didn't express myself clearly. Let me try again:

Vanilla webgl takes a [stride](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebGLRenderingContext/vertexAttribPointer) that is a number of *bytes*, making the above use case possible (using a InterleavedBuffer with a 3 Float32 position InterleavedBufferAttribute and a one Int8 classification attributes). The stride would be therefore 13 (3*4 + 1).

In THREE.js, `InterleavedBuffer` takes a number of *elements* as `stride`, making this use case infeasible (yes I know I can pad my data as a workaround).

This is not a call for help (I should have left out the `what would the best way to achieve that?` above, I thought maybe I didn't see something). It's a feature request/bug report (not sure where to draw the line here): in my opinion three.js should mimic webgl api here.

What's your opinion here?

Thanks for your answer :-)
/ping @benaadams Can you please explain why you defined `stride`, `itemSize`, and `offset` with units of _elements_ rather than _bytes_? Thanks in advance.

Non-aligned data causes issues as the driver then needs to rearrage the buffer to align the data before sending it to gpu.

> ### [Avoid Misaligned Vertex Data](https://developer.apple.com/library/archive/documentation/3DDrawing/Conceptual/OpenGLES_ProgrammingGuide/TechniquesforWorkingwithVertexData/TechniquesforWorkingwithVertexData.html#//apple_ref/doc/uid/TP40008793-CH107-SW7)
>
> When you are designing your vertex structure, align the beginning of each attribute to an offset that is either a multiple of its component size or 4 bytes, whichever is larger. When an attribute is misaligned, iOS must perform additional processing before passing the data to the graphics hardware.
>
> In Figure 8-4, the position and normal data are each defined as three short integers, for a total of six bytes. The normal data begins at offset 6, which is a multiple of the native size (2 bytes), but is not a multiple of 4 bytes. If this vertex data were submitted to iOS, iOS would have to take additional time to copy and align the data before passing it to the hardware. To fix this, explicitly add two bytes of padding after each attribute.
